a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix ([[2, 3], [0, 1]])"
shows  "matrix_pow A 20 - 2 * matrix_pow A 19 = matrix ([[0, 3], [0, -1]])"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.$  Find $\mathbf{A}^{20} - 2 \mathbf{A}^{19}.$ The final Answer is  \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} 
 ### Proof
 First, we can write $\mathbf{A}^{20} - 2 \mathbf{A}^{19} = \mathbf{A}^{19} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}).$  We can compute that \[\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} - 2
 \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} .\]Then \[\mathbf{A} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}
 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} = \mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}.\]Then for any positive integer $n \ge 2,$ \begin{align} \mathbf{A}^n (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) &= \mathbf{A}^{n - 1} \cdot \mathbf{A} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\
 &= \mathbf{A}^{n - 1} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\ \end{align}Hence, \begin{align} \mathbf{A}^{20} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) &= \mathbf{A}^{19} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\ &= \mathbf{A}^{18} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\
 &= \dotsb \\ &= \mathbf{A}^2 (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\ &= \mathbf{A} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\ &= \mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I} \\ &= \boxed{ \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} }. \end{align}
 *)

a_1.formal problem:

shows  "matrix_pow A 20 - 2 * matrix_pow A 19 = matrix([[0, 3], [0, -1]])"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.$  Find $\mathbf{A}^{20} - 2 \mathbf{A}^{19}.$ The final Answer is  \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} 
 ### Proof
 First, we can write $\mathbf{A}^{20} - 2 \mathbf{A}^{19} = \mathbf{A}^{19} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}).$  We can compute that \[\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} - 2
 \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} .\]Then \[\mathbf{A} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}
 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} = \mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}.\]Then for any positive integer $n \ge 2,$ \begin{align} \mathbf{A}^n (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) &= \mathbf{A}^{n - 1} \cdot \mathbf{A} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\
 &= \mathbf{A}^{n - 1} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\ \end{align}Hence, \begin{align} \mathbf{A}^{20} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) &= \mathbf{A}^{19} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\ &= \mathbf{A}^{18} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\
 &= \dotsb \\ &= \mathbf{A}^2 (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\ &= \mathbf{A} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\ &= \mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I} \\ &= \boxed{ \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} }. \end{align}
 *)

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "int^2^2" and B :: "int^2^2"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[2,3],[0,1]])"
and h1 : "B = A powr 20 - 2 * A powr 19"

a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.$  Find $\mathbf{A}^{20} - 2 \mathbf{A}^{19}.$ The final Answer is  \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} 
 ### Proof
 First, we can write $\mathbf{A}^{20} - 2 \mathbf{A}^{19} = \mathbf{A}^{19} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}).$  We can compute that \[\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} - 2

 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} = \mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}.\]Then for any positive integer $n \ge 2,$ \begin{align} \mathbf{A}^n (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) &= \mathbf{A}^{n - 1} \cdot \mathbf{A} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\
 &= \mathbf{A}^{n - 1} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\ \end{align}Hence, \begin{align} \mathbf{A}^{20} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) &= \mathbf{A}^{19} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\ &= \mathbf{A}^{18} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\
 &= \dotsb \\ &= \mathbf{A}^2 (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\ &= \mathbf{A} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\ &= \mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I} \\ &= \boxed{ \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} }. \end{align}
 *)

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "A = mat 2 2 (\<lambda>(i, j). if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then 2 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then 3 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then 1 else 0)"
shows  "matrix_pow 20 A - 2 * matrix_pow 19 A = mat 2 2 (\<lambda>(i, j). if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then 3 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then -1 else 0)"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.$  Find $\mathbf{A}^{20} - 2 \mathbf{A}^{19}.$ The final Answer is  \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} 
 ### Proof
 First, we can write $\mathbf{A}^{20} - 2 \mathbf{A}^{19} = \mathbf{A}^{19} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}).$  We can compute that \[\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} - 2
 \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} .\]Then \[\mathbf{A} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}
 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} = \mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}.\]Then for any positive integer $n \ge 2,$ \begin{align} \mathbf{A}^n (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) &= \mathbf{A}^{n - 1} \cdot \mathbf{A} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\
 &= \mathbf{A}^{n - 1} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\ \end{align}Hence, \begin{align} \mathbf{A}^{20} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) &= \mathbf{A}^{19} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\ &= \mathbf{A}^{18} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\
 &= \dotsb \\ &= \mathbf{A}^2 (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\ &= \mathbf{A} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\ &= \mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I} \\ &= \boxed{ \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} }. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "A = mat 2 2 (\<lambda>(i, j). if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then 2 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then 3 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then 1 else 0)"
shows  "matrix_pow 20 A - 2 * matrix_pow 19 A = mat 2 2 (\<lambda>(i, j). if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then 3 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then -1 else 0)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem:
Given a 2x2 matrix $A$ with elements defined as follows:

- $A_{11} = 2$,
- $A_{12} = 3$,
- $A_{21} = 0$,
- $A_{22} = 1$,

calculate the result of $A^{20} - 2 * A^{19}$. The resulting matrix should have the following elements:

- The element at the first row and second column is $3$,
- The element at the second row and second column is $-1$,
- All other elements are $0$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[2,3],[0,1]])"
shows  "(A ^^ 20) - (2 *^ (A ^^ 19)) = matrix([[0,3],[0,-1]])"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.$  Find $\mathbf{A}^{20} - 2 \mathbf{A}^{19}.$ The final Answer is  \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} 
 ### Proof
 First, we can write $\mathbf{A}^{20} - 2 \mathbf{A}^{19} = \mathbf{A}^{19} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}).$  We can compute that \[\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} - 2
 \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} .\]Then \[\mathbf{A} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}
 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} = \mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}.\]Then for any positive integer $n \ge 2,$ \begin{align} \mathbf{A}^n (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) &= \mathbf{A}^{n - 1} \cdot \mathbf{A} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\
 &= \mathbf{A}^{n - 1} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\ \end{align}Hence, \begin{align} \mathbf{A}^{20} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) &= \mathbf{A}^{19} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\ &= \mathbf{A}^{18} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\
 &= \dotsb \\ &= \mathbf{A}^2 (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\ &= \mathbf{A} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\ &= \mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I} \\ &= \boxed{ \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} }. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[2,3],[0,1]])"
shows  "(A ^^ 20) - (2 *^ (A ^^ 19)) = matrix([[0,3],[0,-1]])"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Calculate the difference between the 20th power of the matrix [[2,3],[0,1]] and twice its 19th power. The final answer is [[0,3],[0,-1]].

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. A 0 $ i $ j = (if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then 2 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then 3 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then 1 else 0)"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> A n = A (n-1) ** A 0"
shows  "A 20 - 2 * (A 19) = (matrix (\<lambda> i j. if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then 0 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then 3 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then -1 else 0))"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.$  Find $\mathbf{A}^{20} - 2 \mathbf{A}^{19}.$ The final Answer is  \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} 
 ### Proof
 First, we can write $\mathbf{A}^{20} - 2 \mathbf{A}^{19} = \mathbf{A}^{19} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}).$  We can compute that \[\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} - 2
 \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} .\]Then \[\mathbf{A} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}
 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} = \mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}.\]Then for any positive integer $n \ge 2,$ \begin{align} \mathbf{A}^n (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) &= \mathbf{A}^{n - 1} \cdot \mathbf{A} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\
 &= \mathbf{A}^{n - 1} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\ \end{align}Hence, \begin{align} \mathbf{A}^{20} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) &= \mathbf{A}^{19} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\ &= \mathbf{A}^{18} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\
 &= \dotsb \\ &= \mathbf{A}^2 (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\ &= \mathbf{A} (\mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I}) \\ &= \mathbf{A} - 2 \mathbf{I} \\ &= \boxed{ \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} }. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. A 0 $ i $ j = (if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then 2 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then 3 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then 1 else 0)"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> A n = A (n-1) ** A 0"
shows  "A 20 - 2 * (A 19) = (matrix (\<lambda> i j. if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then 0 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then 3 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then -1 else 0))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: We are given a sequence of 2x2 matrices $A_n$ defined as follows: the matrix $A_0$ has entries $2, 3, 0, 1$ in positions $(1,1), (1,2), (2,1), (2,2)$ respectively and all other entries are $0$. For any natural number $n \geq 1$, the matrix $A_n$ is the matrix product of $A_{n-1}$ and $A_0$. We want to find the entries of the matrix $A_{20} - 2A_{19}$. The result is a 2x2 matrix where the entries in positions $(1,1), (1,2), (2,1), (2,2)$ are $0, 3, 0, -1$ respectively and all other entries are $0$.
